<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">ORTEP view of a selected part of the crystal structure of [Cd((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-mal)] showing the tridimensional covalent network. The ellipsoids enclose 50% of the electronic density. The dashed lines indicate the intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Symmetry operators for generating equivalent positions: (a) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (b) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (c) 3/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>y, −1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (d) 3/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>x, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>y, 1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (e) −1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 3/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (f) 1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 3/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (g) 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>,1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>,−1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  ORTEP view of a selected part of the crystal structure of [Cd((S)-mal)] showing the tridimensional covalent network. The ellipsoids enclose 50% of the electronic density. The dashed lines indicate the intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Symmetry operators for generating equivalent positions: (a) x, -1+ y, z; (b) x, 1+ y, z; (c) 3/2- x, 1-y, -1/2+ z; (d) 3/2-x, 1-y, 1/2+ z; (e) -1/2+ x, 3/2- y, -z; (f) 1/2+ x, 3/2- y, -z; (g) 2- x,1/2+ y,-1/2- z.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View of the crystal structure of [Cd((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-mal)] along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis showing (a) the three-dimensional network of the Cd atoms connected through the malate ligands and b) the arrangement of the edge-sharing enneahedra.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  View of the crystal structure of [Cd((S)-mal)] along the b-axis showing (a) the three-dimensional network of the Cd atoms connected through the malate ligands and b) the arrangement of the edge-sharing enneahedra.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A new chiral 3D covalent polymer based on chiral bridging ligands, the coordination environment around the Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> being pentagonal bipyramidal.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A new chiral 3D metal-organic coordination polymer [Cd((S)-mal)] (mal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>malic acid), has been solvothermally synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR, TG and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Colorless crystals crystallize in the orthorhombic system, space group P2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.804(1), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.488(2), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.997(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>577.35 (2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 and <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0298. The structure of the compound exhibits a chiral 3D covalent framework based on chiral bridging ligands, the coordination environment around the Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> is pentagonal bipyramidal.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new chiral 3D covalent polymer based on chiral bridging ligands, the coordination environment around the CdII being pentagonal bipyramidal.

Abstract

A new chiral 3D metal-organic coordination polymer [Cd((S)-mal)] (mal=malic acid), has been solvothermally synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR, TG and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Colorless crystals crystallize in the orthorhombic system, space group P212121, a =6.804(1), b =8.488(2), c =9.997(3)Å, V =577.35 (2)Å3, Z =4 and R 1 =0.0298. The structure of the compound exhibits a chiral 3D covalent framework based on chiral bridging ligands, the coordination environment around the CdII is pentagonal bipyramidal.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Carboxylate complexes continue to be much investigated due to their interesting coordination chemistry allowing for unusual structural features, leading to various physical and chemical properties and practical applications as dyes, extractants, drugs, pesticides, catalysts . Their rational synthesis is still currently under special investigation especially for the design of new Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOF’s) . Metal carboxylates are also much involved in biological-related processes , and their chemistry is efficient for the design of low-dimensional magnetic systems with outstanding properties . For this purpose, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>-hydroxycarboxylic acids, exhibiting a variety of coordination abilities and the tendency to form architectures with multidimensional frameworks, are appealing ligands for building simple new chiral coordination compounds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Carboxylate complexes continue to be much investigated due to their interesting coordination chemistry allowing for unusual structural features, leading to various physical and chemical properties and practical applications as dyes, extractants, drugs, pesticides, catalysts . Their rational synthesis is still currently under special investigation especially for the design of new Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOF's) . Metal carboxylates are also much involved in biological-related processes , and their chemistry is efficient for the design of low-dimensional magnetic systems with outstanding properties . For this purpose, α-hydroxycarboxylic acids, exhibiting a variety of coordination abilities and the tendency to form architectures with multidimensional frameworks, are appealing ligands for building simple new chiral coordination compounds .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">We reported recently the synthesis, characterization and magnetic properties of new families of magnetic compounds using (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>)-2-hydroxyphenylacetic acid ((<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>)-mandelic acid) , 2-methoxyphenylacetic acid (methoxymandelic acid) (as a racemic mixture) , and the optically pure ligand (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-2-hydroxy-2-methyl-butanedioic acid ((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-citramalic acid) . Moreover, we obtained a series of magnetic manganese(II), cobalt(II), nickel(II), copper(II), iron(II) and zinc(II) malates (2-hydroxybutanedioate) in which four coordination modes of the dicarboxylate ligand were identified . All the compounds have been obtained using hydrothermal synthesis. Depending on whether the starting malic acid was the racemic mixture or the pure <ce:italic>S</ce:italic> enantiomer, different dimensionalities of the metal based magnetic framework were obtained leading to a variety of magnetic behaviors.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We reported recently the synthesis, characterization and magnetic properties of new families of magnetic compounds using (R)-2-hydroxyphenylacetic acid ((R)-mandelic acid) , 2-methoxyphenylacetic acid (methoxymandelic acid) (as a racemic mixture) , and the optically pure ligand (S)-2-hydroxy-2-methyl-butanedioic acid ((S)-citramalic acid) . Moreover, we obtained a series of magnetic manganese(II), cobalt(II), nickel(II), copper(II), iron(II) and zinc(II) malates (2-hydroxybutanedioate) in which four coordination modes of the dicarboxylate ligand were identified . All the compounds have been obtained using hydrothermal synthesis. Depending on whether the starting malic acid was the racemic mixture or the pure S enantiomer, different dimensionalities of the metal based magnetic framework were obtained leading to a variety of magnetic behaviors.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">As a continuation of our researches on the synthesis of new chiral inorganic coordination polymers using α-hydroxy carboxylates, we report in this paper the synthesis by solvothermal route (see .), crystal structure, spectroscopic properties and thermal behavior of a chiral Cd-(<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-malate ((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-2-hydroxy-butanedioate) exhibiting a new coordination mode for this dicarboxylate ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As a continuation of our researches on the synthesis of new chiral inorganic coordination polymers using α-hydroxy carboxylates, we report in this paper the synthesis by solvothermal route (see .), crystal structure, spectroscopic properties and thermal behavior of a chiral Cd-(S)-malate ((S)-2-hydroxy-butanedioate) exhibiting a new coordination mode for this dicarboxylate ligand.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The crystal structure of [Cd((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-mal)], determined from single crystal diffraction [ and .] corresponds to a 3D coordination framework of interconnected Cd(II)O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> polyhedra. The asymmetric unit contains one independent Cd(II) ion. Selected distances and angles are reported in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, each Cd(II) centre is surrounded by seven oxygen atoms forming a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal site. All oxygen atoms are provided by six different malate ligands (O1; O2d; O3d; O4a; O5a; O4e; O5f). The oxygen atoms provided by the organic ligands belong to the carboxylate group, except the O3d atom, which belongs to a hydroxo group in α position. Each Cd(II) centre is connected to four neighboring Cd(II) ions via carboxylato and/or oxo bridges with metal–metal distances <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M-M</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5.73(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the carboxylato bridges and 3.93(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the oxo bridges (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>), respectively. The sequence of the polyhedra (enneahedral) is ensured by two ways. One involves carboxylato bridges (O1–C1–O2) with a conformation <ce:italic>syn-anti</ce:italic> and a Cd–Cd distance of 5.73(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and carboxylato bridges (O4–C4–O5) with a conformation <ce:italic>anti–anti</ce:italic> with a Cd–Cd distance of 6.80(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The second way is built by only one oxygen atom of the carboxylate group (O4) with a distance of 3.90(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å between related Cd atoms (). The enneahedral sites formed around each Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion are distorted and the metal-oxygen bonds vary from 2.19<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å to 2.69<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, very similar to corresponding distances in other cadmium complexes .  shows the tridimensional arrangement (3D network) of the enneahedra in the crystal structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of [Cd((S)-mal)], determined from single crystal diffraction [ and .] corresponds to a 3D coordination framework of interconnected Cd(II)O7 polyhedra. The asymmetric unit contains one independent Cd(II) ion. Selected distances and angles are reported in  . As shown in  , each Cd(II) centre is surrounded by seven oxygen atoms forming a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal site. All oxygen atoms are provided by six different malate ligands (O1; O2d; O3d; O4a; O5a; O4e; O5f). The oxygen atoms provided by the organic ligands belong to the carboxylate group, except the O3d atom, which belongs to a hydroxo group in α position. Each Cd(II) centre is connected to four neighboring Cd(II) ions via carboxylato and/or oxo bridges with metal-metal distances d M-M =5.73(1)Å for the carboxylato bridges and 3.93(1)Å for the oxo bridges ( ), respectively. The sequence of the polyhedra (enneahedral) is ensured by two ways. One involves carboxylato bridges (O1-C1-O2) with a conformation syn-anti and a Cd-Cd distance of 5.73(1)Å and carboxylato bridges (O4-C4-O5) with a conformation anti-anti with a Cd-Cd distance of 6.80(1)Å. The second way is built by only one oxygen atom of the carboxylate group (O4) with a distance of 3.90(1)Å between related Cd atoms (). The enneahedral sites formed around each CdII ion are distorted and the metal-oxygen bonds vary from 2.19Å to 2.69Å, very similar to corresponding distances in other cadmium complexes .  shows the tridimensional arrangement (3D network) of the enneahedra in the crystal structure.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Each malate ligand is coordinated to five cadmium atoms. One carboxylate (O1–C1–O2) bridges Cd and Cdc in a <ce:italic>syn-anti</ce:italic> configuration, the other (O4–C4–O5) bridges Cde and Cdf in the <ce:italic>anti–anti</ce:italic> configuration. In addition, O4 and O5 are chelating Cdb. The oxygen O3 of the alcoholic moieties is chelating Cdc with O2. This coordination mode is different from the four other modes observed in the first raw transition metal malate series .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each malate ligand is coordinated to five cadmium atoms. One carboxylate (O1-C1-O2) bridges Cd and Cdc in a syn-anti configuration, the other (O4-C4-O5) bridges Cde and Cdf in the anti-anti configuration. In addition, O4 and O5 are chelating Cdb. The oxygen O3 of the alcoholic moieties is chelating Cdc with O2. This coordination mode is different from the four other modes observed in the first raw transition metal malate series .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The TGA trace in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor> revealed that the decomposition takes place in one step. The slight decrease observed between 25 and 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be assigned to the loss of some adsorbed water. Then, the steep weight loss between 340 and 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is associated to the decomposition of [Cd((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-mal)]. It is worth noting that this decomposition occurs at quite high temperature and that the combustion of the hydrocarbon part of the compound is very exothermic, leading to an overflow of the temperature regulation. The final total weight loss of 43% corresponds well to the decomposition of [Cd((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-mal)] into CdO (calc. 47.4%).</ce:para>

Then, the steep weight loss between 340 and 400°C is associated to the decomposition of [Cd((S)-mal)]. It is worth noting that this decomposition occurs at quite high temperature and that the combustion of the hydrocarbon part of the compound is very exothermic, leading to an overflow of the temperature regulation. The final total weight loss of 43% corresponds well to the decomposition of [Cd((S)-mal)] into CdO (calc. 47.4%).

The absorptions at 2950 and 2930<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> correspond to the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(CH) and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) stretching modes. The absorption bands observed at 1560 and 1424<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are assigned to the anti-symmetrical and symmetrical C–O vibrations, and the difference, Δ<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>136<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, is much smaller than that observed with the corresponding acid (Δ<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>299<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) as expected for the observed coordination modes of the carboxylic groups . The absorption band for the C–O vibration of the alcoholic group of the malate ligands is observed at <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 1114<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and is much broader than observed in the first raw transition metal malates . It can be due to the peculiar multidentate coordination to the Cd atoms and also to the involvement of the alcoholic function in strong hydrogen bonding as denoted in

elements.clean_text: The infrared spectrum of [Cd((S)-mal)] recorded between 400 and 4000cm-1 confirms the structural analysis ( ). The absorptions at 2950 and 2930cm-1 correspond to the ν(CH) and ν(CH2) stretching modes. The absorption bands observed at 1560 and 1424cm-1 are assigned to the anti-symmetrical and symmetrical C-O vibrations, and the difference, Δν =136cm-1, is much smaller than that observed with the corresponding acid (Δν a =299cm-1) as expected for the observed coordination modes of the carboxylic groups . The absorption band for the C-O vibration of the alcoholic group of the malate ligands is observed at ca. 1114cm-1 and is much broader than observed in the first raw transition metal malates . It can be due to the peculiar multidentate coordination to the Cd atoms and also to the involvement of the alcoholic function in strong hydrogen bonding as denoted in  . Accordingly, a broad and intense band characteristic of the H-bonded OH is observed at 3265cm-1.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, the solvothermal synthesis, single crystal structure, thermal and spectroscopic properties of a new cadmium(II) chiral coordination polymer has been presented. This structure consists in a 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>D framework of oxygen edge-sharing enneahedra surrounding the metal ions which are interconnected by carboxylate and oxo groups. Compared to the first raw transition metal analogues, the malate ligand exhibits an original pentadentate coordination mode with the cadmium atoms. Strong hydrogen bonds involving the alcoholic OH moieties were observed. Moreover, the present compound shows a good thermal stability, decomposing in air only above 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, the solvothermal synthesis, single crystal structure, thermal and spectroscopic properties of a new cadmium(II) chiral coordination polymer has been presented. This structure consists in a 3D framework of oxygen edge-sharing enneahedra surrounding the metal ions which are interconnected by carboxylate and oxo groups. Compared to the first raw transition metal analogues, the malate ligand exhibits an original pentadentate coordination mode with the cadmium atoms. Strong hydrogen bonds involving the alcoholic OH moieties were observed. Moreover, the present compound shows a good thermal stability, decomposing in air only above 330°C.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">CCDC 635029 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.05.037" xlink:type="simple">doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.06.001</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new chiral 3D covalent polymer based on chiral bridging ligands, the coordination environment around the CdII being pentagonal bipyramidal.

Abstract

A new chiral 3D metal-organic coordination polymer [Cd((S)-mal)] (mal=malic acid), has been solvothermally synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR, TG and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Colorless crystals crystallize in the orthorhombic system, space group P212121, a =6.804(1), b =8.488(2), c =9.997(3)Å, V =577.35 (2)Å3, Z =4 and R 1 =0.0298. The structure of the compound exhibits a chiral 3D covalent framework based on chiral bridging ligands, the coordination environment around the CdII is pentagonal bipyramidal.

The crystal structure of [Cd((S)-mal)], determined from single crystal diffraction [ and .] corresponds to a 3D coordination framework of interconnected Cd(II)O7 polyhedra. The asymmetric unit contains one independent Cd(II) ion. Selected distances and angles are reported in  . As shown in  , each Cd(II) centre is surrounded by seven oxygen atoms forming a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal site. All oxygen atoms are provided by six different malate ligands (O1; O2d; O3d; O4a; O5a; O4e; O5f). The oxygen atoms provided by the organic ligands belong to the carboxylate group, except the O3d atom, which belongs to a hydroxo group in α position. Each Cd(II) centre is connected to four neighboring Cd(II) ions via carboxylato and/or oxo bridges with metal-metal distances d M-M =5.73(1)Å for the carboxylato bridges and 3.93(1)Å for the oxo bridges ( ), respectively. The sequence of the polyhedra (enneahedral) is ensured by two ways. One involves carboxylato bridges (O1-C1-O2) with a conformation syn-anti and a Cd-Cd distance of 5.73(1)Å and carboxylato bridges (O4-C4-O5) with a conformation anti-anti with a Cd-Cd distance of 6.80(1)Å. The second way is built by only one oxygen atom of the carboxylate group (O4) with a distance of 3.90(1)Å between related Cd atoms (). The enneahedral sites formed around each CdII ion are distorted and the metal-oxygen bonds vary from 2.19Å to 2.69Å, very similar to corresponding distances in other cadmium complexes .  shows the tridimensional arrangement (3D network) of the enneahedra in the crystal structure.

The TGA trace in   revealed that the decomposition takes place in one step. The slight decrease observed between 25 and 300°C can be assigned to the loss of some adsorbed water. Then, the steep weight loss between 340 and 400°C is associated to the decomposition of [Cd((S)-mal)]. It is worth noting that this decomposition occurs at quite high temperature and that the combustion of the hydrocarbon part of the compound is very exothermic, leading to an overflow of the temperature regulation. The final total weight loss of 43% corresponds well to the decomposition of [Cd((S)-mal)] into CdO (calc. 47.4%).

The infrared spectrum of [Cd((S)-mal)] recorded between 400 and 4000cm-1 confirms the structural analysis ( ). The absorptions at 2950 and 2930cm-1 correspond to the ν(CH) and ν(CH2) stretching modes. The absorption bands observed at 1560 and 1424cm-1 are assigned to the anti-symmetrical and symmetrical C-O vibrations, and the difference, Δν =136cm-1, is much smaller than that observed with the corresponding acid (Δν a =299cm-1) as expected for the observed coordination modes of the carboxylic groups . The absorption band for the C-O vibration of the alcoholic group of the malate ligands is observed at ca. 1114cm-1 and is much broader than observed in the first raw transition metal malates . It can be due to the peculiar multidentate coordination to the Cd atoms and also to the involvement of the alcoholic function in strong hydrogen bonding as denoted in  . Accordingly, a broad and intense band characteristic of the H-bonded OH is observed at 3265cm-1.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Table 2. Hydrogen bond parameters determined by the PLATON software

| Type  | Donor–HAcceptor_[ARU][^*] | D–H (Å) | HA (Å) | DA (Å)   | D–HA (°) |
|-------|--------------------------|---------|--------|----------|---------|
| Intra | O3–H3O2_g                | 0.95    | 2.02   | 2.736(5) | 130     |
| Intra | C(2)–H(2)O1_f            | 1.00    | 2.45   | 3.446(6) | 172     |
| Intra | C(3)–H(3B)O(1)           | 0.99    | 2.44   | 2.859(6) | 105     |

[^*]: The operators for generating equivalent atoms (g and f) are defined in Fig. 1.
data: Bond & Angle type of table is not target

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">ORTEP view of a selected part of the crystal structure of [Cd((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-mal)] showing the tridimensional covalent network. The ellipsoids enclose 50% of the electronic density. The dashed lines indicate the intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Symmetry operators for generating equivalent positions: (a) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (b) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (c) 3/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>y, −1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (d) 3/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>x, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>y, 1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (e) −1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 3/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (f) 1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 3/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (g) 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>,1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>,−1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  ORTEP view of a selected part of the crystal structure of [Cd((S)-mal)] showing the tridimensional covalent network. The ellipsoids enclose 50% of the electronic density. The dashed lines indicate the intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Symmetry operators for generating equivalent positions: (a) x, -1+ y, z; (b) x, 1+ y, z; (c) 3/2- x, 1-y, -1/2+ z; (d) 3/2-x, 1-y, 1/2+ z; (e) -1/2+ x, 3/2- y, -z; (f) 1/2+ x, 3/2- y, -z; (g) 2- x,1/2+ y,-1/2- z.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View of the crystal structure of [Cd((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-mal)] along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis showing (a) the three-dimensional network of the Cd atoms connected through the malate ligands and b) the arrangement of the edge-sharing enneahedra.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  View of the crystal structure of [Cd((S)-mal)] along the b-axis showing (a) the three-dimensional network of the Cd atoms connected through the malate ligands and b) the arrangement of the edge-sharing enneahedra.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">TGA and TDA curves of [Cd((<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-mal)].</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  TGA and TDA curves of [Cd((S)-mal)].

metadata.title: Synthesis, crystal structure and spectroscopic properties of a new chiral cadmium (II) malate
